contentItem.text: Aardvarks are digging machines! They have massive, powerful claws that are like having a shovel on each finger. An aardvark can dig himself underground in 5 minutes flat! But why dig so much? Aardvarks make homes underground to hide from predators. And it's a great tool to get at their favorite food -Termites!

contentItem.text: Aardvarks eat almost nothing but termites and ants. They don't have teeth, but they do have two other features that help them get at their food. They have Digging Power to bust open the concrete-like termite mounds. Plus, a long, sticky tongue to slurp up the little snacks.
Aardvarks roam all over Africa. They're super secretive and hard to find. Plus, they travel huge distances. Since they're such great diggers, they can just make a new burrow wherever they go.

Lions, Hyenas, and Leopards all eat aardvarks if they can catch them above ground. If attacked, an aardvark will first try to dig underground. But if there is no time, they'll use their long claws to slash at their enemy and defend themselves.

Aardvarks dig so many burrows that they end up making homes for lots of creatures on the African savannah. Here are just a few of the animals that use old aardvark burrows as their homes: Caracal cats, South African Shelducks, Warthogs, Spotted Hyenas, African Rock Pythons, Porcupines, and Monitor Lizards.
